evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. outcome.reasoning_summary: The history evidence (H1-H4) directly documents the pushback event involving the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t0_prelim, including the tug driver roles, pushback actions, and the aircraft moving beyond the Tug release point, confirming availability of procedural deviation data for analysis.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H2-H4 directly describe the procedural deviation during pushback for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25, showing the deviation aligns with key features such as seat swapping, pushback continuation, and overshoot beyond the TRP.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution demonstrates resistance to defeaters within the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t0_prelim.

assumptions: Procedural deviation is indicated by the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier
Resistance to defeaters implies preventing or correcting deviations to avoid incident
defeaters: Evidence of successful prevention of deviation or error correction preventing incident
Clear demonstration that procedural deviation was managed without adverse outcome

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows a procedural deviation occurred (H4) and that the instructor took over and attempted to correct the pushback (H2, H3), but the aircraft still overran the TRP, indicating limited resistance to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence on whether the deviation was resisted or mitigated effectively; outcome suggests failure to resist.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, involved personnel, and operational context.

The interaction between tug instructor and trainee driver reflects communication dynamics relevant to the incident
defeaters: Explicit evidence of effective communication and coordination without breakdown
Evidence showing the incident was caused by factors other than communication/coordination
More detailed timeline or communication logs contradicting the breakdown

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows multiple personnel involved in pushback communication and coordination (H1, H2, H3) and an operational context where the aircraft moved beyond the intended stop point causing an incident (H4). This aligns with key features of communication/coordination breakdown in timing, personnel, and context, though direct explicit statements of breakdown are not present.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit statements confirming communication/coordination breakdown; ambiguity in interpreting actions as breakdown

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
